-LCz2zwve2ZAN7pMQqBU.foodForThought: How will the recent school shooting in Texas affect the ongoing national debate over gun control? What can be done to prevent these kind of deadly attacks in schools?
-LCz2zwve2ZAN7pMQqBU.name: The Texas School Shooting

-LD4i0-tiU5a6gNYb_Jd.description:
• On Monday, U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that the United States and China have reached a short-term truce in their trade conflict.
  • The United States agreed to suspend its threat of $150B in tariffs on Chinese goods. In exchange, China agreed to "substantially reduce" America's trade deficit with China, but did not commit to a specific number.
  • Global markets responded favorably to the news of suspended tariffs.
-LD4i0-tiU5a6gNYb_Jd.foodForThought: What is the best long-term fix for the United States' trade deficit with China? If Trump's move to suspend his $150B tariff threat a good one?
-LD4i0-tiU5a6gNYb_Jd.name: A Thaw in the U.S.-China Trade Dispute?
-LD4i0-tiU5a6gNYb_Jd.shortTitle: A Thaw in the U.S.-China Trade Dispute?

-LD9rMGrNK2ytu6DUxH5.description:
• On Monday, Netflix announced a multi-year production deal with Michelle and Barack Obama.
  • The Obamas will produce a diverse mix of content, which could include both scripted and unscripted series, documentaries and features. Their content will reach over 125M global viewers in 190 countries.
  • According to Michelle Obama, "Netflix’s unparalleled service is a natural fit for the kinds of stories we want to share, and we look forward to starting this exciting new partnership.”
-LD9rMGrNK2ytu6DUxH5.foodForThought: Is the deal good for Netflix? Good for the Obamas? Good for the country?
-LD9rMGrNK2ytu6DUxH5.name: The Obamas' Deal with Netflix

-LDEmZ0DoeSBzbVAcV3D.description:
• June 12 is the scheduled date for a historic summit between President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Many hoped the summit would mark a significant potential step toward diplomacy and ultimately the denuclearization of North Korea.
  • However, recent events have cast doubt on whether the summit will occur as planned.
  • In the last week, North Korea has appeared to be reconsidering the highly anticipated meeting, citing particular objection to comments made by US National Security Adviser John Bolton suggesting North Korean disarmament could be modeled after Libya's voluntary denuclearization in 2003. President Trump denied any plan to pursue a swift, Libya-type model with North Korea.
  • On Tuesday, President Trump suggested the summit could be canceled or delayed, stating: “There’s a very substantial chance that it won’t work out, and that’s O.K. That doesn’t mean it won’t work over a period of time. But it may not work out for June 12.”
-LDEmZ0DoeSBzbVAcV3D.foodForThought: What will be the repercussions if the summit with North Korea is cancelled? What is the best strategy for the United States to adopt when it comes to North Korea?
-LDEmZ0DoeSBzbVAcV3D.name: Summit with North Korea in Question
-LDEmZ0DoeSBzbVAcV3D.shortTitle: Summit with North Korea in Question

-LDJ230s3iHbLatUwoS0.description:
• On Wednesday, the NFL announced changes to league policy regarding the national anthem.
  • The new policy lifts the requirement that players must be present on the field for the anthem, but allows for penalization of players present for the anthem who protest.
  • The policy change comes amidst a lengthy controversy in the NFL that began in 2016 when quarterback Colin Kaepernick took a knee during the national anthem to protest police brutality.
  • Reactions to NFL player protests during the national anthem have been polarized: some decry the actions as shameful and disrespectful, while others see them as brave and meaningful.
-LDJ230s3iHbLatUwoS0.foodForThought: What are the motivations behind the new NFL national anthem policy? Is the policy a fair one?
-LDJ230s3iHbLatUwoS0.name: The New NFL National Anthem Policy

-LDcSzmKQOdbngWHeEU4.description:
• Last week, Ireland held a referendum on its controversial Eighth Amendment. This amendment had effectively banned abortion by recognizing the equal right to life of a pregnant woman and an unborn fetus.
  • The referendum results were more lopsided than expected, with ~66% voting to repeal the abortion ban. Now, the Irish government will be allowed to legislate on terminations.
  • Turnout for the referendum was ~64% and results indicate that there was a large gulf in the views held by older and younger generations.
  • For now, the abortion ban still applies in Northern Ireland.
-LDcSzmKQOdbngWHeEU4.foodForThought: How should one interpret Ireland's referendum results? Is Ireland moving away from its Catholic roots?
-LDcSzmKQOdbngWHeEU4.name: Ireland's Landmark Abortion Referendum

-LDifozRyfY5J1vv_KI6.description:
• Over the weekend, LeBron James's Cleveland Cavaliers won the NBA's Eastern Conference title over the Boston Celtics. They will face the Golden State Warriors in the NBA finals.
  • After LeBron's strong Game 7 performance against the Celtics, many basketball fans have decided to strike up an old debate: who is the greatest of all time (GOAT) of the NBA?
  • Strong arguments have been made made for both LeBron James and Michael Jordan. Jordan has 6 championships to LeBron's 3. However, LeBron is about to play in his 8th consecutive NBA finals.
-LDifozRyfY5J1vv_KI6.foodForThought: Who, in your opinion, is the greatest NBA player of all time? LeBron James or Michael Jordan?
-LDifozRyfY5J1vv_KI6.name: LeBron James Vs. Michael Jordan

-LDmzJsodmzRhvh1cHlc.description:
• On Tuesday, ABC cancelled its popular show, "Roseanne".
  • The show was cancelled after the star of the show, Roseanne Barr, published a racist tweet.
  • Roseanne's tweet stated, "muslim brotherhood & planet of the apes had a baby = vj."
  • "VJ" is a reference to former Obama advisor, Valerie Jarrett. Jarrett issued a statement in which she said, "This should be a teaching moment. #EverydayRacism."
  • "Roseanne" was a reboot of a show that ran between 1988 and 1997. It aimed to realistically portray a working-class, American family, and the lead character, played by Roseanne, was a Trump supporter.
  • The rebooted show achieved great early ratings. Over 25M viewers watched its premiere on March 27th.
-LDmzJsodmzRhvh1cHlc.foodForThought: Do you think that ABC handled the situation appropriately? Is Roseanne's punishment consistent with that received by other public figures who post offensive messages?
-LDmzJsodmzRhvh1cHlc.name: ABC Cancels Roseanne after Racist Tweet

-LDsJPl8RQd3EaDXgRaM.description:
• On Wednesday, President Trump signed the "Right to Try" Act.
  • The U.S. House of Representatives passed the act on Tuesday, with a 250 - 169 vote. The Senate passed the bill back in August.
  • This act allows terminally ill patients to use experimental drugs that have not been fully approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
  • To qualify under this act, experimental drugs still must pass the FDA's first approval phase. This means they have to prove that they don't harm humans.
-LDsJPl8RQd3EaDXgRaM.foodForThought: Should you support the passage of "Right to Try" legislation? Why or why not?
-LDsJPl8RQd3EaDXgRaM.name: Should Terminally Ill Patients have a "Right to Try" Experimental Drugs?

-LE5sXFiDKBP0hPlf9GM.description:
• On Friday, June 1st, the United States Department of Labor released its May Jobs Report.
  • The U.S. economy added 223,000 net (non-farm) jobs in May.
  • Unemployment fell to 3.8%, the lowest rate in 18 years.
  • The unemployment rate for African-Americans fell to 5.9%, the lowest ever on record.
  • This is the 92nd consecutive month in which the United States has seen job growth.
  • Year-over-year wage growth reached 2.7%.
  • Prior to the release of the jobs report, President Trump drew rebukes for tweeting, "Looking forward to seeing the employment numbers at 8:30 this morning."
-LE5sXFiDKBP0hPlf9GM.foodForThought: Is the strong economy a result of a natural cycle or should it be attributed to President Trump's policies? Was President Trump's tweet out of line?
-LE5sXFiDKBP0hPlf9GM.name: The May Jobs Report

-LEBSfsWf0bVcnRAw2lr.description:
• On Monday, the Supreme Court issued a ruling in its case, "Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission."
  • This case arose after a baker, Jack Phillips, refused to bake a custom cake for a wedding between two gay men, David Mullins and Charlie Craig.
  • The Court ruled in favor of Jack Phillips via a 7-2 vote based on extremely narrow grounds. They claimed that the Colorado Commission had made statements that demonstrated its hostility to Phillip's religious beliefs. Justice Anthony Kennedy delivered the majority opinion, in which he also strongly reaffirmed protections for LGBTQ rights.
  • The Court's ruling doesn't provide an answer to the question of whether a business can discriminate against LGBTQ people under the religious freedom protections in the First Amendment. Its decision was meant to be limited to the facts of this specific case.
-LEBSfsWf0bVcnRAw2lr.foodForThought: Did you think that the Supreme Court got this case right? Did the Court make a good decision by punting on many of the bigger questions associated with this case?
-LEBSfsWf0bVcnRAw2lr.name: Wedding Cakes, Gay Rights and Religious Freedom

-LEFEfutnDVoaKe-IKzn.description:
• On June 4th, President Trump tweeted, "As has been stated by numerous legal scholars, I have the absolute right to PARDON myself, but why would I do that when I have done nothing wrong?..."
  • Back in January, President Trump's lawyers sent a letter to Special Counsel Mueller in which they argued that as head of the Justice Department, President Trump could, "if he wished, terminate the [Russia] inquiry, or even exercise his power to pardon if he so desired."
  • Article II, Section 2, Clause 1 of the U.S. Constitution states that the President "shall have Power to grant Reprieves and Pardons for Offenses against the United States, except in Cases of Impeachment."
  • Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuiliani, has also been in the headlines. He said that President Trump has the power to self-pardon, but doing so would be "unthinkable."
-LEFEfutnDVoaKe-IKzn.foodForThought: Does President Trump have the legal authority to pardon himself? How would a potential court rule in such a case?
-LEFEfutnDVoaKe-IKzn.name: Can President Trump Pardon Himself?

-LENSsCkX0a4nu32p0xW.description:
• On Tuesday, the Miss America organization announced it would be eliminating the iconic swimsuit competition from its annual pageant.
  • The Miss America beauty pageant first began in the 1920s to select “the most beautiful bathing girl in America,” but in more recent years contestants have been judged on interviews and talent performances in addition to physical appearance.
  • The competition is open to women from the United States between the ages of 17 and 25, and the winner of the title spends the following year traveling around the country promoting causes of interest.
  • The next Miss America celebration will see the removal of both the swimsuit and traditional evening gown competitions, changes that reflect the organization’s hope to shift focus away from the physical appearance of its competitors.
  • Gretchen Carlson, chair of Miss America’s board of directors, stated: “We will no longer judge our candidates on their outward physical appearance,” a significant change in nature intended to make the pageant more “open, transparent, inclusive to woman who may not have felt comfortable participating in our program before.”
-LENSsCkX0a4nu32p0xW.foodForThought: Was eliminating the swimsuit competition a good decision for Miss America? Does the pageant's pivot away from physical appearance carry broader societal significance?
-LENSsCkX0a4nu32p0xW.img_attr: Staff Sgt. Jessica Barnett, Public Domain
-LENSsCkX0a4nu32p0xW.name: Miss America Drops Swimsuit Competition

-LEQQfHroinyjqcT3TlN.description:
• Tuesday saw the biggest night in the midterm election primaries season, with these eight states holding primary elections: Alabama, California, Iowa, Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota.
  • The primaries included key races for Senate, House, and Gubernatorial positions.
  • Democrats would need to flip 23 seats in November to win back a majority in the House, and 2 seats to gain control in the Senate.
  • California is of particular importance to Democrats, with seven contendable House seats currently held by Republicans.
  • California’s primary system, often referred to as a “jungle primary,” pushes only the top two winners from each primary election to the general election, regardless of party. Most of California’s primary elections on Tuesday pushed both a Democrat and a Republican on to November’s general election.
-LEQQfHroinyjqcT3TlN.foodForThought: What predictions, if any, can be made about November's midterm elections after Tuesday's primaries? Do the results indicate optimism for Republicans, Democrats, both?
-LEQQfHroinyjqcT3TlN.name: Takeaways from Tuesday's Primaries

-LEj3Hvx80tX9XEEyhnG.description:
• The Group of Seven (G7) is composed of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.
  • The G7 meets annually to discuss issues like international security, energy policy and the global economy.
  • This year's G7 summit was held June 8th - 9th in Quebec, Canada.
  • At the end of the summit, US President Trump refused to sign a joint statement called the G7 Communique.
  • This Communique was meant to articulate shared priorities among the seven nations.
  • In addition, President Trump threatened to escalate trade wars with America's neighbors and called Canada's President, Justin Trudeau, "very dishonest and weak."
-LEj3Hvx80tX9XEEyhnG.foodForThought: What are countries like the UK, Germany, and Canada saying about the recent G7 summit? What is US President Donald Trump saying?
-LEj3Hvx80tX9XEEyhnG.mobile_img_attr: Official White House Photo by Shealah Craighead
-LEj3Hvx80tX9XEEyhnG.name: President Trump at the G7 Summit
-LEj3Hvx80tX9XEEyhnG.shortTitle: President Trump at the G7 Summit

-LEog-0EnRuI9xL8JZRF.description:
• U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un held their highly-awaited summit in Singapore on June 12th, 2018.
  • The summit included a high-profile handshake between the two leaders.
  • After an exchange of opinions, Trump and Kim signed and issued a 2-page joint statement.
  • President Trump committed to provide security guarantees to North Korea and agreed to suspend joint military exercises with South Korea.
  • Kim Jong-Un reaffirmed his commitment to the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula but didn’t provide a detailed timeline or plans.
  • Both leaders committed to recovering POW / MIA remains and promised the immediate repatriation of already-identified remains.
  • Trump and Kim agreed to hold follow-on negotiations, led by U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and a relevant high-level North Korean official.
-LEog-0EnRuI9xL8JZRF.foodForThought: Did this summit make you more skeptical or more hopeful about the potential for peace on the Korean peninsula?
-LEog-0EnRuI9xL8JZRF.mobile_img_attr: Official White House Photo by Shealah Craighead
-LEog-0EnRuI9xL8JZRF.name: The Trump - Kim Summit

-LEqYocnyIlqrJye4v3S.description:
• On Tuesday, AT&T won court approval to purchase Time Warner Inc. for $85 billion.
  • AT&T is one of the world's largest telecommunications companies. Time Warner controls popular content including HBO, TBS, TNT and CNN.
  • The deal was first announced in October 2016. Trump, still a candidate, vowed that he would try to block the deal.
  • In November 2017, the Justice Department sued AT&T on anti-trust grounds. The Justice Department said that its decision was not influenced by the White House.
  • Yesterday, Judge Leon dismissed the case by issuing a 172-page opinion. He argued that the Justice Department did not present sufficient evidence to support its claim that the vertical merger would harm competition.
  • Many say that this decision clears the way for Comcast to challenge Disney by bidding for 21st Century Fox.
-LEqYocnyIlqrJye4v3S.foodForThought: Are you critical of the ruling or supportive of it? What's next now that the deal is approved?
-LEqYocnyIlqrJye4v3S.name: The $85B AT&T and Time Warner Deal
-LEqYocnyIlqrJye4v3S.shortTitle: The $85B AT&T and Time Warner Deal

-LEvabJmGQM3PmUiCFxS.description:
• Bird, an electric scooter startup, is raising a new funding round of $300M at a $2B company valuation.
  • Bird has doubled its valuation in a very short period of time. Just last month, Bird raised a round of $150M at a $1B valuation.
  • Bird was founded by Travis VanderZanden, a former Uber and Lyft executive.
  • There are two other fast-growing electric scooter companies, Spin and LimeBike.
  • The three companies are quickly expanding to cities across the United States such as San Francisco, L.A., and Atlanta.
  • Here's how most of these electric scooters work: through an app, users can find and ride any available dockless electric scooter. They pay a per-minute usage fee and drop off the scooters wherever they want once their trip ends.
  • When these companies expand to cities, they typically bring thousands of scooters and scatter them across city sidewalks.
-LEvabJmGQM3PmUiCFxS.foodForThought: Do you think that electric scooters are the next big thing? Are companies like Bird, LimeBike and Spin worthy of their high valuations?
-LEvabJmGQM3PmUiCFxS.name: Are Electric Scooters Deserving of the Hype?
-LEvabJmGQM3PmUiCFxS.shortTitle: Electric Scooters Deserving of the Hype?

-LF0cv8zZv0EtDSXWf1a.description:
• The 21st FIFA Men's World Cup began on Thursday, June 14th in Russia. The tournament is held every four years.
  • The opening matchup featured Russia and Saudi Arabia. Russia won, 5-0.
  • Group play takes place between June 14th and June 28th and will be followed by the Round of 16 which kicks off on June 30th. The World Cup final is scheduled for July 15th.
  • 32 teams qualified for the World Cup. The United States was not one of them.
  • Brazil, Spain, France and Germany (the defending champion) are among the favorites.
  • Iceland and Panama are in the tournament for the first time ever.
-LF0cv8zZv0EtDSXWf1a.foodForThought: What are different countries writing about the World Cup? What do you think is the most interesting storyline in this year's tournament?
-LF0cv8zZv0EtDSXWf1a.name: The 2018 World Cup - Views from Around the World

-LFHtD7cJwGgTqXajOgW.description:
• In April, US Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a new "zero-tolerance" policy prohibiting illegal entry and attempted illegal entry into the US by an alien.
  • "Zero-tolerance" means that all cases of illegal entry are referred for criminal prosecution. Since US protocol prohibits detaining children with their parents when the parent is charged with a crime, this has resulted in children being separated from their parents.
  • The US Department of Homeland Security says that between April 19th and May 31st, nearly 2,000 minors were separated from their families at the border.
  • This figure was not broken down by age and it included separations due to immigration violations, illegal entry and possible criminal conduct by the adult.
  • The Justice Department and the Department of Homeland Security say the children are being well-cared for at the border and promise that no mothers have been separated from infant children.
  • Last Thursday, Sessions said, "I would cite you to the Apostle Paul and his clear and wise command in Romans 13, to obey the laws of the government because God has ordained them for the purpose of order."
-LFHtD7cJwGgTqXajOgW.foodForThought: Is there any justification for separating children from their families at the US border? What are Democrats and Republicans saying about this issue?
-LFHtD7cJwGgTqXajOgW.name: Separating Kids from Parents at the Border?

-LFNTsqtlwCkdi3nGmH5.description:
• On Monday, the Supreme Court issued rulings on two cases involving partisan gerrymandering.
  • The first case came from Wisconsin and involved a redistricting plan designed by Republican legislators.
  • The second came from Maryland and involved a challenge against Democrats’ efforts to redraw a district.
  • The Supreme Court sent the first case back to lower courts in Wisconsin, and unanimously ruled against Democrats in Maryland, stating they had waited too long in their attempt.
  • The Supreme Court ruling effectively left the issue of partisan gerrymandering unresolved for now.
-LFNTsqtlwCkdi3nGmH5.foodForThought: Did the Supreme Court do the right thing by punting on another gerrymandering case? Is this an issue that should be addressed by the Court?
-LFNTsqtlwCkdi3nGmH5.name: The Supreme Court's Gerrymandering Decision

-LFPiY3-lqZZLSeFXcW-.description:
• On Monday, President Trump signed an executive order that seeks to create a new branch of the US military called the Space Force.
  • Trump directed the Pentagon and the Department of Defense to "immediately begin the process necessary to establish a Space Force."
  • The Pentagon responded to President Trump's order and said that its Policy Board will begin working on a vision for the new branch.
  • The creation of any new military branch requires Congressional approval.
  • The last time this happened was in 1947 when the Air Force was created.
-LFPiY3-lqZZLSeFXcW-.foodForThought: Do you think that the establishment of a separate Space Force is a good idea? Why or why not?
-LFPiY3-lqZZLSeFXcW-.name: President Trump's Space Force

-LFXP1qlPqrG5ZBXjlHS.description:
• On Monday, President Trump proposed new tariffs, set at a 10% rate, on $200 billion of Chinese imports.
  • The proposed tariffs are the latest in a series of tariffs imposed on Chinese goods, to which China has responded with their own tariffs against US exports.
  • This escalation has set the two nations toward a trade war, and President Trump has said he will continue to raise tariffs if China continues to retaliate.
  • In the past President Trump has said that in these kind of cases, trade wars are “good, and easy to win.”
  • The United States has also imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum from allies like Mexico, Canada, and the EU.
  • Various allies, including the EU, India, and Turkey, have responded with retaliatory tariffs on US exports.
-LFXP1qlPqrG5ZBXjlHS.foodForThought: What are the arguments for and against tariffs? Do you approve of the Trump Administration's trade policies?
-LFXP1qlPqrG5ZBXjlHS.name: Tariffs and an Escalating Trade War
-LFXP1qlPqrG5ZBXjlHS.shortTitle: Tariffs and an Escalating Trade War

-LFbde7N08kCguwDsI8q.description:
• In April, Attorney General Jeff Sessions implemented a zero-tolerance policy for prosecuting every adult who illegally entered, or attempted to enter, the country by crossing the Mexican border.
  • The resulting separation of minors and children from their families elicited much public condemnation and backlash.
  • On Wednesday, President Trump signed an executive order which stated that the administration’s policy will now be to keep families together once detained.
  • The executive order does not lift the zero-tolerance policy, but does order agencies to use or build facilities “for the housing and care of alien families.”
  • On Thursday, the Department of Justice asked a federal district court to modify the Flores Settlement, a ruling that prohibits the federal government from keeping children in immigration detention centers for more than 20 days.
  • This week, Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) proposed the Protect Kids and Parents Act.
  • Cruz's bill would keep families together while providing resources that would allow asylum claims to be processed within 14 days. After 14 days, legal families would be granted asylum and families without papers would be sent back home.
-LFbde7N08kCguwDsI8q.foodForThought: How would you grade President Trump's response to the border crisis? What is the best long-term solution?
-LFbde7N08kCguwDsI8q.name: An Update on the Border Crisis
-LFbde7N08kCguwDsI8q.shortTitle: An Update on the Border Crisis

-LFoTfR6nsCv4ZqwZEgX.description:
• On Friday, June 22nd, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was dining at a restaurant called Red Hen in Lexington, Virginia.
  • While dining, Sanders was approached by the owner of the restaurant, Stephanie Wilkinson, and was asked to leave.
  • Wilkinson defended her decision to kick out Sanders, saying, “I explained that the restaurant has certain standards that I feel it has to uphold, such as honesty, and compassion, and cooperation… I said, 'I'd like to ask you to leave.”
  • Sanders tweeted about the incident on Saturday night and said, “Last night I was told by the owner of Red Hen in Lexington, VA to leave because I work for @POTUS and I politely left. Her actions say far more about her than about me. I always do my best to treat people, including those I disagree with, respectfully and will continue to do so.”
-LFoTfR6nsCv4ZqwZEgX.foodForThought: Was the owner of the restaurant justified in her decision to kick out Sanders?
-LFoTfR6nsCv4ZqwZEgX.name: Sarah Huckabee Sanders Kicked Out of Restaurant

-LFw_TXJUWVzenzhwPEi.description:
• The United States continues to grapple with illegal immigration along its southern border, implementing a “zero-tolerance” policy meant to dramatically reduce illegal border crossings.
  • On June 24, 2018, Donald Trump tweeted that illegal immigrants “invade our Country” and should be sent home “with no Judges or Court Cases.”
  • He argued that the current process is unfair to those who legally pursue immigration, as “immigration must be based on merit.”
  • This suggested removal of due process has generated controversy and inspired debate over the constitutional rights of illegal immigrants.
-LFw_TXJUWVzenzhwPEi.foodForThought: What are the implications of President Trump's latest tweets regarding immigration policy at the border?
-LFw_TXJUWVzenzhwPEi.name: President Trump's Recent Immigration Tweets

-LFxwnho9J7vl3PYgBd4.description:
• Yesterday the Supreme Court, in a 5-4 ruling, upheld President Trump’s travel ban in case Trump v. Hawaii.
  • The case pertained to the third iteration of the president’s executive order and accompanying travel ban, which the court allowed into legal effect in early December, pending legal challenges.
  • The travel ban restricts travel to the United States from seven countries: Iran, Libya, North Korea, Somalia, Syria, Venezuela, and Yemen (Chad was on the list in November but has been removed).
  • Chief Justice Roberts delivered the majority opinion, which determined the ban is within the executive authority of the president, citing the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952.
  • The Supreme Court also issued rulings in two other important cases yesterday and Monday: National Institute of Family and Life Advocates v. Becerra (related to crisis pregnancy centers, abortion, and free speech) and Ohio v. American Express Co. (related to antitrust law, two-sided markets, and policies about merchants steering customers to use credit cards with lower transaction fees).
-LFxwnho9J7vl3PYgBd4.foodForThought: Did the Supreme Court make the right decision? What are the consequences of the ruling?
-LFxwnho9J7vl3PYgBd4.img_attr: Franz Jantzen, Collection of the Supreme Court of the United States
-LFxwnho9J7vl3PYgBd4.name: Supreme Court Upholds Travel Ban

-LG21Z8EYuKVjh1OqZ18.description:
• Yesterday Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy announced his retirement from the Court, effective July 31st.
  • Justice Kennedy was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Ronald Reagan in 1987.
  • Under the Roberts court, Justice Kennedy was considered by many to have the “swing vote” when it came to determining a final ruling.
  • Though labeled a traditionally conservative judge, it is not easy to classify Justice Kennedy’s ideology in broad strokes. He treated cases individually, often siding with his more conservative colleagues on the court but voting against them on some key rulings celebrated by liberals.
  • A few of the impactful 5-4 rulings decided by Justice Kennedy include Obergefell v. Hodges, which effectively legalized same-sex marriage; Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, which dramatically changed political campaign finance law; Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania v. Casey, which upheld abortion rights established by Roe V. Wade; and the most recent Trump v. Hawaii, which upheld President Trump’s travel ban.
-LG21Z8EYuKVjh1OqZ18.foodForThought: What kind of legacy does Justice Kennedy leave behind? What will his retirement mean for the future of the Supreme Court?
-LG21Z8EYuKVjh1OqZ18.name: The Legacy of Justice Anthony Kennedy
-LG21Z8EYuKVjh1OqZ18.shortTitle: The Legacy of Justice Anthony Kennedy

-LGB05r0z0fvZJTG0YVm.description:
• The group stage of the World Cup has finished, sending half of the original 32 teams home. 
  • The remaining 16 teams will advance to the knockout stage, culminating in the World Cup Final game on Sunday, July 15.
  • While the group phase sees teams competing in round robin style tournaments amongst their groups, the knockout stage features single elimination matches, with overtime and penalty kicks to determine a winner if necessary.
  • Some highlights of the group stage include: Argentina's surprisingly perilous advancement, Japan closely edging out Senegal, and the shocking elimination of Germany, the World Cup defending champion.
  • The 16 teams advancing are Uruguay, Russia, Spain, Portugal, France, Denmark, Croatia, Argentina, Brazil, Switzerland, Sweden, Mexico, Belgium, England, Colombia, and Japan.
-LGB05r0z0fvZJTG0YVm.foodForThought: What have been the highs and lows of the World Cup so far? Who will emerge victorious in the knockout stage?
-LGB05r0z0fvZJTG0YVm.name: An Update on the 2018 World Cup
-LGB05r0z0fvZJTG0YVm.shortTitle: An Update on the 2018 World Cup

-LGQ0idGRAfaL2krfrtY.description:
• On Sunday, Mexican citizens elected Andrés Manuel Lopéz Obrador as their new president.
  • Lopéz Obrador (often referred to as AMLO) campaigned with a left-leaning platform and promised to fight violence and corruption while addressing poverty.
  • AMLO won more than half of the votes, giving him one of the largest mandates of any Mexican president in decades. 
  • The President-elect says that he will pay for many of his proposed social programs by eliminating corruption. He has promised not to raise Mexico’s debt and says he will maintain close ties with the United States.
  • This was AMLO's third bid for the Mexican presidency.
-LGQ0idGRAfaL2krfrtY.foodForThought: What were the factors in Sunday's elections in Mexico? What do the election results mean for the future of the country?
-LGQ0idGRAfaL2krfrtY.name: Mexico's Presidential Election

-LGVNz6rDlmr1nqywGoz.description:
• Last Sunday night, NBA superstar LeBron James announced his four-year, $154 million deal with the Los Angeles Lakers.
  • His resume includes: 4 NBA MVP awards, 3 NBA Championships (2 with the Miami Heat, 1 with the Cleveland Cavaliers), and 8 straight NBA Finals appearances.
  • LeBron grew up playing basketball in Akron, Ohio and was chosen as the first overall draft pick by the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2003.
  • He played for the Cavaliers from 2003 - 2010, the Miami Heat from 2010 - 2014, and the Cavaliers again from 2014 - 2018.
-LGVNz6rDlmr1nqywGoz.foodForThought: Are you disappointed or excited by LeBron's decision? What does it mean for the NBA? For fans from different cities?
-LGVNz6rDlmr1nqywGoz.name: LeBron Joins the Lakers

-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.description:
The date is July 4th, 1776...

  • The Second Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence on July 4th, 1776 at the Pennsylvania State House, Independence Hall in Philadelphia.
  • This declaration said that the 13 colonies were independent, sovereign states and were no longer part of the British Empire.
  • The colonies and the British Empire have been fighting each other in a Revolutionary War since the Battles of Lexington and Concord, which took place on April 19th, 1775.
-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.foodForThought: Should America declare independence from Great Britain, or seek a more peaceful resolution?
-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.img_attr: US Air Force graphic by Staff Sgt Joseph McKee
-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.img_attr_url: Official United States Air Force Website
-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.mobilePhotoPath: -LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1/Should America Declare Independence from Great Britain?.jpg
-LGWr9MCBa2CHHt19Zl1.name: Should America Declare Independence from Great Britain?

-LGec5LIGIehRRr_UPjx.description:
• Last Wednesday, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy announced his upcoming retirement.
  • Now, President Trump is evaluating potential nominees for the Supreme Court vacancy. 
  • Two of the leading contenders are Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh and Judge Amy Coney Barrett. 
  • Kavanaugh, a Yale graduate, currently serves on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. He served as a staff secretary for former President George W. Bush and clerked for Justice Anthony Kennedy. 
  • Barrett, a former law professor at Notre Dame, is a recent appointee to the Chicago-based U.S. 7th Circuit Court of Appeals. She was a former law clerk for Justice Antonin Scalia.
  • President Trump has reportedly met with six contenders: Kavenaugh, Barrett, Raymond Kethledge, Amul Thapar, Joan Larsen, and Thomas Hardiman.
-LGec5LIGIehRRr_UPjx.foodForThought: How should potential Supreme Court nominees be evaluated? What are the chief arguments for and against the candidates on President Trump's short list?
-LGec5LIGIehRRr_UPjx.name: Potential SCOTUS Nominees Barrett and Kavanaugh

-LGjbZwX_xWLwFVwFuoJ.description:
• On July 5, Scott Pruitt resigned from his role as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, effective immediately.
  • When President Trump nominated Pruitt to the position, he stated that the EPA “has spent taxpayer dollars on an out-of-control anti-energy agenda,” and promised that Pruitt would “reverse this trend and restore the EPA’s essential mission.”
  • Over his tenure as head of the EPA, Pruitt drew controversy over a variety of suspected ethical violations, including misuse of taxpayer funds and exploitation of a public office for private gain.
  • Scott Pruitt stated in his resignation letter: “the unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family, are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on all of us.”
  • President Trump tweeted, “I have accepted the resignation of Scott Pruitt as the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Within the Agency Scott has done an outstanding job, and I will always be thankful to him for this.”
-LGjbZwX_xWLwFVwFuoJ.foodForThought: How should Scott Pruitt's legacy at the EPA be characterized? What were the factors that led to his resignation?
-LGjbZwX_xWLwFVwFuoJ.name: Scott Pruitt's Resignation

-LGzDmPQZuD4q64tmc7P.description:
• On Friday, July 6, the tariffs on Chinese imports proposed by the Trump Administration went into effect.
  • The tariffs equate to a 25% tax on over 818 imported Chinese products, worth around $34 billion a year in imports.
  • The administration originally proposed the tariffs in April, and in mid-June the White House announced the list of Chinese products targeted. 
  • Once the tariffs went into effect, China immediately imposed retaliatory tariffs on $34 billion worth of American imports. The products targeted by China include cars, airplanes, soybeans, and whiskey.
  • China’s Ministry of Commerce also released an official statement on Friday in response to the United States’ original tariffs, stating: “The United States violated the World Trade Organization [WTO] rules and launched the largest trade war in economic history to date.”
-LGzDmPQZuD4q64tmc7P.foodForThought: Has the United States started an official trade war with China? How will the economic repercussions affect Americans and the global trade market?
-LGzDmPQZuD4q64tmc7P.name: President Trump's Trade War?

-LH3T5dmT0JI3HoZWmMb.description:
• Last night, July 9th, President Trump announced his pick to replace Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, who announced his retirement two weeks ago.
  • President Trump nominated Brett Kavanaugh, a current United States Circuit Judge. 
  • Early in his career, Kavanaugh clerked for Justice Kennedy. He then served as Assistant to the President and White House Staff Secretary during the presidency of George W. Bush.
  • President Bush nominated Kavanaugh to his current seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
  • The next step for Kavanaugh will be a series of meetings with individual senators before the official confirmation process.
-LH3T5dmT0JI3HoZWmMb.foodForThought: Is Brett Kavanaugh a good candidate for the Supreme Court? What are Republicans and Democrats saying about him?
-LH3T5dmT0JI3HoZWmMb.mobilePhotoPath: -LH3T5dmT0JI3HoZWmMb/Brett Kavanaugh Nominated to the Supreme Court .jpg
-LH3T5dmT0JI3HoZWmMb.name: Brett Kavanaugh Nominated to the Supreme Court

-LH8J9mBCdiJw4Jh_mmF.description:
• Last Friday, July 6th, the US Bureau of Labor Statistics released its June jobs report.
  • In June, the United States economy added 213,000 jobs.
  • Last month, unemployment rose by 0.2%, from 3.8% in May to 4.0% in June. It is still near historically low levels.
  • Work force participation rose by 0.2% last month, bringing the total level to 62.9%.
  • Average hourly wages are 2.7% higher than they were last year. This number is considered by many to be stubbornly low, especially since prior to the recession, annual wage growth was well over 3% for hourly workers.
  • Since unemployment is so low, many economists are hoping to see wage growth accelerate over the coming months.
-LH8J9mBCdiJw4Jh_mmF.foodForThought: How should you interpret the numbers in the June jobs report?
-LH8J9mBCdiJw4Jh_mmF.name: The June Jobs Report

-LHDSncDeyZOvPpzc3DE.description:
• Yesterday, July 11th, marked the opening of a 2-day NATO summit in Brussels, Belgium.
  • NATO, which stands for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is a security alliance that was established in 1949 to counter the perceived Soviet threat. It now has 29 member states across North America and Europe. 
  • Independent NATO member states adhere to a policy of collective defense. This means that an attack by an external party on one member state is considered to be an attack on all.
  • US President Trump is an outspoken critic of NATO's funding structure. This morning, he tweeted: “Presidents have been trying unsuccessfully for years to get Germany and other rich NATO Nations to pay more toward their protection from Russia. They pay only a fraction of their cost. The U.S. pays tens of Billions of Dollars too much to subsidize Europe, and loses Big on Trade!”
  • Russia is not a member of NATO, but President Trump plans to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on July 16th.
-LHDSncDeyZOvPpzc3DE.foodForThought: Were President Trump’s actions at the NATO summit justified or inappropriate? What is the best funding structure for NATO?
-LHDSncDeyZOvPpzc3DE.name: President Trump at the NATO Summit
-LHDSncDeyZOvPpzc3DE.shortTitle: President Trump at the NATO Summit

-LHJM6rAtNAV5VRbTtqM.description:
• Peter Strzok (pronounced "struck") is an FBI agent who led the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server and later worked on Mueller’s special counsel investigation into Russian election interference.
  • Strzok was removed from the special counsel investigation once it was discovered he had exchanged disparaging texts about Donald Trump with colleague Lisa Page, with whom he was having an affair.
  • Republican members of Congress have used these texts to question Strzok’s impartiality while conducting the Russia investigation.
  • On Thursday, The House Judiciary and Oversight Committees held a contentious, ten-hour hearing to further examine Strzok’s behavior during his tenure at the FBI, as part of a greater investigation into allegations of political bias in the justice department. 
  • The hearing featured intense partisan shouting matches, cursing, and harsh criticism from both sides.
  • Strzok maintained during testimony that his personal beliefs did not have an impact on his work at the FBI.
-LHJM6rAtNAV5VRbTtqM.foodForThought: Why did Thursday’s congressional hearing become so combative? Who, if anyone, is to blame?
-LHJM6rAtNAV5VRbTtqM.name: The Controversial Strzok Congressional Hearing

-LHYQH14w6pBm0g-4qO6.description:
• On Thursday, President Trump arrived in London for his first official visit to the UK since becoming President.
  • Large crowds of demonstrators gathered around London on Friday to protest Trump’s visit. The protests included various marches organized by several different groups.
  • Protesters cited a range of grievances with the US President, including his policies and behavior related to immigration, race relations, and climate change.
  • Organizers have stated that over 250,000 people were in attendance at the protests, but London Police say they do not release official crowd size estimates.
  • One of the larger gatherings took place in London’s Parliament Square, where a prominent, 20 ft caricature balloon was flown above the crowd. The balloon depicted Trump as an orange baby in a diaper, clutching a cell phone.
  • President Trump departed London on Friday for Scotland, where subsequent protests were also held over the weekend.
-LHYQH14w6pBm0g-4qO6.foodForThought: Are the anti-Trump protests in the UK effective, disrespectful, or both? What is the role of protest in 2018?
-LHYQH14w6pBm0g-4qO6.name: Anti-Trump Protests in the UK

-LHcjkqRNlCFtDMARqGo.description:
• Yesterday, July 16th, President Trump attended a summit meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki, Finland.
  • This marked the first official meeting between the two world leaders, following some unofficial talks at previous global summits in Germany and Vietnam.
  • The summit was intended to improve US-Russia relations, which have been deteriorating due to Russia's annexing of Crimea in 2014 and potential interference in the 2016 United States presidential election, among other factors.
  • In the post-summit joint press conference, President Trump spoke highly of the talks, stating: “I have just concluded a meeting with President Putin on a wide range of critical issues for both of our countries. We had direct, open, deeply productive dialogue. Went very well."
  • President Putin similarly called the summit “a success and a very fruitful round of negotiations.”
  • The press conference elicited some immediate bipartisan criticism in the United States, with much of the disapproval aimed at President Trump’s apparent acceptance of Putin’s denial of Russian election interference in 2016.
-LHcjkqRNlCFtDMARqGo.foodForThought: Was Trump’s behavior a betrayal to Americans or a promising sign for future relations between America and Russia?
-LHcjkqRNlCFtDMARqGo.name: The Trump-Putin Summit in Helsinki

-LHf7sLBr8XKSoAMV8ea.description:
• Elon Musk is the founder and CEO of SpaceX, the co-founder and CEO of Tesla, and was the largest shareholder in PayPal when it was acquired by eBay for $1.5B.
  • Musk has been largely well-renowned and praised as a visionary, receiving numerous awards and much acclaim for his work. However, recent erratic behavior and hostile media relations have threatened Elon Musk's public reputation.
  • Most notable were his actions over the last several weeks regarding the efforts to rescue the boys' soccer team from the Thailand cave. Musk offered to help with a mini-submarine built by SpaceX engineers, but when his efforts were denied and described as impractical, he lashed out at a member of the rescue team.
  • Musk targeted rescue cave diver Vern Unsworth on twitter, at one point making an unsubstantiated insinuation that Unsworth was a pedophile. The tweet was subsequently deleted, and this morning Elon Musk tweeted an apology.
-LHf7sLBr8XKSoAMV8ea.foodForThought: How significant are Elon Musk's recent public actions? Will they inflict long-lasting damages on his businesses or reputation?
-LHf7sLBr8XKSoAMV8ea.name: What's up with Elon Musk?

-LHn12MrEf5YYJ-7uLFo.description:
• On Monday, July 16th, President Trump and President Putin met for a summit in Helsinki, followed by a joint press conference.
  • After the summit, a significant number of Republican and Democratic lawmakers issued harsh condemnations of President Trump’s press conference comments.
  • On Tuesday, President Trump said he misspoke in the press conference on the topic of Russian election interference.
  • Trump stated, “The sentence should have been, ‘I don’t see any reason why I wouldn’t, or why it wouldn’t be Russia’” instead of “why it would.” He also reiterated his faith in US intelligence agencies.
  • The president did not address or back down on any other comments from the press conference and later tweeted: “The meeting between President Putin and myself was a great success, except in the Fake News Media!”
  • On Thursday, in an interview with CBS News, President Trump said he told President Putin that Russian election interference must stop and that he would hold Putin personally responsible. He stated: “I let him know we can’t have this. We’re not going to have it and that’s the way it’s going to be.”
-LHn12MrEf5YYJ-7uLFo.foodForThought: Was it a good idea for President Trump to reverse his press conference comments about Russian election interference? Did his comments do enough to address criticisms?
-LHn12MrEf5YYJ-7uLFo.name: The Aftermath of the Trump - Putin Summit
-LHn12MrEf5YYJ-7uLFo.shortTitle: Aftermath of the Trump - Putin Summit

-LHroj6cebJJ5-7KW7gc.description:
• On Wednesday, July 18th, the European Commission issued a record $5 billion fine against Alphabet-owned Google for abusing the dominance of its Android mobile marketing system.
  • The commission stated that the company’s practice of requiring makers of Android phones to pre-install Google search and browser apps violates European Union antitrust laws.
  • The fine also addressed the limitations Google placed on other operating systems run on Android devices.
  • The EU ordered Google to cease this practice within 90 days to avoid incurring larger fines.
  • Google immediately said it intends to appeal the decision. Google CEO Sundar Pichai tweeted on Wednesday: “Android has created more choice, not less.”
  • ﻿This week’s fine is the largest ever against Google. Last year, the EU slapped Google with a $2.7 billion fine related to its shopping services.
-LHroj6cebJJ5-7KW7gc.foodForThought: Is the $5 billion fine on Google a significant blow for the tech giant? Does it indicate greater changes coming for tech industry competition and regulation?
-LHroj6cebJJ5-7KW7gc.name: EU Fines Google $5 Billion

-LI6UC46ecQsMy5zSkj5.description:
• On Friday, July 20th, it was reported that federal agents seized a recording made two months before the 2016 presidential election by Michael Cohen, ex-attorney of President Trump.
  • The recording reportedly contains a discussion between Cohen and Trump about the possibility of buying the rights to a model’s account of an alleged extramarital affair with the president.
  • The woman in question is Karen Mcdougal, a former playboy centerfold model. Her story about a 2006 affair with Trump was purchased by American Media Inc., the parent company of National Enquirer, but never published.
  • Michael Cohen supposedly recorded the conversation in secret without President Trump’s knowledge.
  • On Saturday, the president tweeted: “Inconceivable that the government would break into a lawyer’s office (early in the morning) - almost unheard of. Even more inconceivable that a lawyer would tape a client - totally unheard of & perhaps illegal. The good news is that your favorite President did nothing wrong!”
-LI6UC46ecQsMy5zSkj5.foodForThought: What is the significance of Cohen’s recording? Will there be consequences for President Trump or his former attorney?
-LI6UC46ecQsMy5zSkj5.name: Michael Cohen's Secret Recording

-LIBdfY3XzfAMu2t4-yK.description:
• On Sunday, July 22, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo gave a speech condemning Iranian leaders’ corruption and human rights violations. In the speech he stated: “The level of corruption and wealth among Iranian leaders shows that Iran is run by something that resembles the mafia more than a government.”
  • Following the speech, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said while addressing a group of Iranian diplomats, “America should know that peace with Iran is the mother of all peace, and war with Iran is the mother of all wars.”
  • On Sunday night, President Trump addressed the Iranian president in an explosive tweet. The tweet read: “To Iranian President Rouhani: NEVER, EVER THREATEN THE UNITED STATES AGAIN OR YOU WILL SUFFER CONSEQUENCES THE LIKES OF WHICH FEW THROUGHOUT HISTORY HAVE EVER SUFFERED BEFORE. WE ARE NO LONGER A COUNTRY THAT WILL STAND FOR YOUR DEMENTED WORDS OF VIOLENCE & DEATH. BE CAUTIOUS!”
  • On Monday, in an apparent response to President Trump, Iran’s Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif tweeted: “COLOR US UNIMPRESSED: The world heard even harsher bluster a few months ago. And Iranians have heard them — albeit more civilized ones — for 40 yrs. We’ve been around for millennia & seen fall of empires, incl our own, which lasted more than the life of some countries. BE CAUTIOUS!”
  • In response to a question about President Trump’s tweet, Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated Monday: “The President has been, I think, pretty strong, since day one, in his language towards Iran. He was responding to comments made from them, and he’s going to continue to focus on the safety and security of American people.”
-LIBdfY3XzfAMu2t4-yK.foodForThought: Is President Trump’s twitter warning to the Iranian President Rouhani a threat of war? What will the consequences of the escalated rhetoric be, if any?
-LIBdfY3XzfAMu2t4-yK.name: Rising Tension with Iran

-LIH0BZ1LTtVGJ7qLf3B.description:
• Sacha Baron Cohen, the British actor and comedian behind movies like Borat and Bruno, is back with a brand new TV show titled Who is America?, which premiered on Showtime on July 15, 2018.
  • Who Is America? is a political mockumentary. Baron Cohen plays a variety of characters, including a far-right conspiracy theorist, a liberal Democratic activist, and an Israeli anti-terrorism expert.
  • In the show, Baron Cohen tricks high-profile celebrities and politicians into participating in ridiculous stunts, including one where Republican representatives voiced their support for arming preschoolers. Those tricked include Sarah Palin, Roy Moore, Bernie Sanders, The Bachelor’s Corinne Olympios, and others.
  • The show’s second episode featured Georgia state Representative Jason Spencer dropping his pants and yelling racial slurs as instructed by Baron Cohen’s Israeli military expert character. Amid political pressure and public backlash, Spencer announced his resignation today, effective at the end of the month.
  • Who Is America? has generated controversy, drawing both criticism and support from viewers.
-LIH0BZ1LTtVGJ7qLf3B.foodForThought: Do Sacha Baron Cohen’s comedic performances and characters in Who is America? cross the line from funny to inappropriate?
-LIH0BZ1LTtVGJ7qLf3B.name: Sacha Baron Cohen's Show Generates Controversy

-LILy0ypzK8VN7s34piC.description:
• Beginning next week on August 1st, it will be legal for Americans to download design plans and 3D print a variety of untraceable firearms, including the AR-15, the weapon used in many mass shootings.
  • The principle company behind the effort is Texas-based Defense Distributed, an online open-sourced organization that aims to develop and freely publish firearm plans and designs, which can be downloaded and reproduced by any owner of a 3D printer.
  • Defense Distributed first began publishing the designs on the internet in 2013, but the United States Department of State quickly ordered them taken down.
  • After years of court battles, Defense Distributed announced on July 10th, 2018, that a settlement had been reached with the Department of State.
  • Cody Wilson, the founder and spokesperson for Defense Distributed, said his plan was to immediately relaunch the company’s original efforts and once again start publishing open-sourced gun designs at the beginning of August.
-LILy0ypzK8VN7s34piC.foodForThought: Are 3D-printable gun designs a danger to public safety? Does this mark the end of gun control in America?
-LILy0ypzK8VN7s34piC.name: The Age of 3D Printable Guns?

-LIRQt457pBb7EtWyJ4K.description:
• The Endangered Species Act is a law that was first passed in 1973. The law’s intent is to protect critically endangered species by halting or reversing their trend toward extinction.
  • The two agencies responsible for administering the law are the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the Commerce Department's National Marine Fisheries Service.
  • The Trump administration, along with a group of congressional Republicans, have proposed rolling back some of the automatic protections, and have introduced legislation to overhaul the ESA.
  • Administration officials said the new rules would advance conservation by simplifying and improving how the landmark Endangered Species Act is used.
  • Many environmental groups and conservationists have voiced concern, saying the proposed changes will undermine the law altogether.
-LIRQt457pBb7EtWyJ4K.foodForThought: What will be the consequences of modernizing the Endangered Species Act? Who is to gain from these government-proposed changes?
-LIRQt457pBb7EtWyJ4K.mobile_img_attr: Maslowski Steve, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
-LIRQt457pBb7EtWyJ4K.name: Changes for the Endangered Species Act?
-LIRQt457pBb7EtWyJ4K.shortTitle: Changes for the Endangered Species Act?

-LIfoh0Co6Nfi8EQb4G1.description:
• Yesterday, July 29th, President Trump tweeted: “I would be willing to ‘shut down’ government if the Democrats do not give us the votes for Border Security, which includes the Wall! Must get rid of Lottery, Catch & Release etc. and finally go to system of Immigration based on MERIT! We need great people coming into our Country!"
  • The tweet contradicts reports that President Trump agreed with top Republican lawmakers in a meeting last week over a strategy to avoid a shutdown.
  • According to reports, the strategy outlined included focusing efforts in Congress on reconciling various appropriation and spending bills before the budget deadline at the beginning of October.
  • Not included in the bills selected to be reconciled was the Department of Homeland Security funding bill that was approved by Budget appropriators in the House of Representatives last Thursday. 
  • Republican leaders in Congress indicated that efforts to reconcile this bill, which provides funding for the border wall, would be postponed.
  • A government shutdown, which would take effect at midnight on September 30th if spending bills are not reconciled, could be politically dangerous for Republicans with midterm elections quickly approaching.
-LIfoh0Co6Nfi8EQb4G1.foodForThought: Should Congress work to approve funding the border wall ahead of the October budget deadline? What is the significance of President Trump’s ‘government shutdown’ tweet?
-LIfoh0Co6Nfi8EQb4G1.mobilePhotoPath: -LIfoh0Co6Nfi8EQb4G1/The Border Wall, Immigration, and a Government Shutdown Threat.jpg
-LIfoh0Co6Nfi8EQb4G1.name: The Border Wall, Immigration, and a Government Shutdown Threat

-LIlFMmImYqFzn3lJIy3.description:
• Yesterday, July 30th, Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced the creation of a new "religious liberty task force" within the Department of Justice.
  • The task force's stated purpose is to protect religious groups in the United States from persecution. 
  • The announcement came during a speech given at the Department of Justice's Religious Liberty Summit in Washington, D.C.
  • In his speech, Sessions stated: "A dangerous movement, undetected by many, is now challenging and eroding our great tradition of religious freedom. There can be no doubt. This is no little matter. It must be confronted and defeated."
  • According to Sessions, the task force will be co-chaired by acting Associate Attorney General Jesse Panuccio and Assistant Attorney General Beth Williams.
-LIlFMmImYqFzn3lJIy3.foodForThought: Will this task force protect religious freedom or endorse discrimination? Is this task force necessary?
-LIlFMmImYqFzn3lJIy3.name: Jeff Sessions Creates Religious Liberty Task Force

-LIqKwwVw55PC3Kb3y7P.description:
• Special counsel Robert Mueller’s trial of Paul Manafort began Tuesday, July 31, in Virginia.
  • Manafort, a notable Republican campaign manager and lobbyist, once served as an advisor in Ukrainian politics. His former clients include the pro-Russian political Party of Regions and the former Ukrainian President Yanukovych.
  • From March to August of 2016, Manafort acted as Trump’s presidential campaign chair.
  • In 2017, Manafort was charged with money laundering, fraud, false income tax returns, failure to report foreign bank assets, and other financial crimes. He has pleaded not guilty on all 18 counts.
  • A second, separate trial awaits Manafort in Washington DC this September, where he will face charges including conspiracy to defraud the United States.
  • None of Manafort’s charges involve President Trump or Russian interference in the 2016 election. However, there has been speculation that Mueller intends to use these charges to pressure Manafort into assisting the special counsel’s Russia Investigation.
-LIqKwwVw55PC3Kb3y7P.foodForThought: What is the significance of the various charges against Manafort? To what degree are his trials connected to Robert Mueller's special council investigation?
-LIqKwwVw55PC3Kb3y7P.name: Paul Manafort's Trial Begins

-LIv3D5TiByt5AIZbVd4.description:
• On July 28, 2018, the Boston Globe broke a story about a secret monitoring program at the TSA named “Quiet Skies.”
  • The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is an agency of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. It has authority over security of the traveling public in the United States and is primarily associated with air travel and airport security.
  • According to the exposé, the domestic surveillance program attempts to minimize threat, directing federal air marshals to follow and collect information on regular US citizens that are not under any agency investigation and are not in the Terrorist Screening Database.
  • Government documents reportedly show that the surveillance collected includes details like “whether passengers fidget, use a computer, have a ‘jump’ in their Adam’s apple or a ‘cold penetrating stare,’ among other behaviors.”
  • The Quiet Skies program has raised concerns about Constitutional rights from groups like the ACLU and by lawmakers.
  • The TSA recently released a statement defending the program, claiming that: “with routine reviews and active management via legal, privacy and civil rights and liberties offices, the program is a practical method of keeping another act of terrorism from occurring at 30,000 feet."
-LIv3D5TiByt5AIZbVd4.foodForThought: Is the TSA’s Quiet Skies program a justified method of defending travelers against potential threats, or is it an invasion or privacy and misuse of public information?
-LIv3D5TiByt5AIZbVd4.name: TSA's Secret 'Quiet Skies' Program

-LIxKkz5TRyu4w2VUBDh.description:
• Last September Senator Bernie Sanders, along with 16 cosponsors, introduced a Medicare-for-All bill in the Senate.
  • The Medicare-for-All proposal would create a federally administered single-payer health care program, with the aim of providing universal health care coverage in the United States. 
  • This week, the Mercatus Center, a libertarian-leaning policy center, released a study estimating the 10-year cost of Sanders’ Medicare-for-All from 2022 to 2031. According to the study, the plan would increase government health spending by $32.6 trillion.
  • Senator Sanders addressed the report in a statement, saying: “This grossly misleading and biased report is the Koch brothers response to the growing support in our country for a ‘Medicare for All’ program.
  • Some claim the results of the Mercatus Center are correct, but that the figure is still lower than comprehensive health care cost projections without the proposal.
-LIxKkz5TRyu4w2VUBDh.foodForThought: Is the inclusive vision of ‘Medicare for All’ worth the $13 trillion government and taxpayer expense? Is this the best solution to America's healthcare problem?
-LIxKkz5TRyu4w2VUBDh.name: 'Medicare for All' Proposal

-LJEiKypQcOtcVwt3LPM.description:
• Recently, a movement to reduce and eliminate the use of plastic straws has gained momentum and popularity.
  • In early July, Starbucks made national headlines when it announced its plans to eliminate the use of plastic straws in its stores by 2020.
  • The city of Seattle recently implemented a ban on non-compostable disposable straws, and other major cities, including New York City and San Francisco, have taken steps toward similar citywide bans.
  • The anti-straw movement stems from environmental concerns over global plastic pollution, particularly its harmful effects on the earth’s ocean habitats.
-LJEiKypQcOtcVwt3LPM.foodForThought: Are plastic straw bans necessary? Will eliminating plastic straws help curb ocean pollution?
-LJEiKypQcOtcVwt3LPM.name: The Anti-Straw Movement

-LJJZQ-KcenHEnBwDukQ.description:
• Multiple social media platforms have recently banned content from Alex Jones, a controversial radio show host and conspiracy theorist.
  • On August 5, 2018, Apple removed selected podcasts made by Jones and his site Infowars from its podcast app.
  • In the wake of Apple’s decision, various media platforms have followed suit. Spotify similarly removed selected podcasts made by Jones, and Youtube cancelled the Infowars channel.
  • Facebook unpublished four pages run by Alex Jones, citing “repeated violations of community standards.”
  • The reasons given for the various social media bans include assertions that Jones’s content glorified violence and contained hate speech.
-LJJZQ-KcenHEnBwDukQ.foodForThought: Are social media platforms taking necessary action by removing content from Alex Jones? Is this action a violation of the first amendment?
-LJJZQ-KcenHEnBwDukQ.name: Should Alex Jones be Banned from Social Media?
-LJJZQ-KcenHEnBwDukQ.shortTitle: Alex Jones Banned from Social Media

-LJOu872myjVJjIsp_kS.description:
• On Monday, August 6th, President Trump signed an executive order reimposing a large number of economic sanctions on Iran, effective immediately.
  • U.S. sanctions against Iran had previously been eased under the terms of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. President Trump withdrew from the deal in May.
  • In a statement Monday, the president reiterated his belief that both the 2015 deal and its subsequent sanction relief for Iran were unacceptable, and that international allies should follow the United States’ example by similarly reducing economic relations with Iran.
  • The decision to reimpose sanctions has been met with opposition from many European government officials, who have stated that the Iran deal's sanction relief was successfully serving its intended purposes.
-LJOu872myjVJjIsp_kS.foodForThought: Will the restored Iran sanctions lead to political reform, or do they impose unnecessary pain?
-LJOu872myjVJjIsp_kS.name: U.S. Reimposes Sanctions on Iran

-LJU5L6Xll7_-Ce5rSz2.description:
• Yesterday, August 8th, New York City became the first US city to place a cap on the number of Uber, Lyft, and other ride-sharing vehicles allowed to operate in the city. 
  • The group of bills approved by the New York City council includes a one-year freeze on new for-hire vehicle licenses and mandates a minimum hourly wage for ride-share drivers.
  • Mayor Bill de Blasio has voiced support for the bill, saying it is necessary to minimize gridlock traffic conditions in the city and improve industry wages. 
  • Rideshare companies and other critics argue that the new law would unnecessarily cripple the transportation industry, making it more difficult and expensive for people to get around the city. 
  • Joseph Okpaku, the vice president of public policy at Lyft, said in a statement, “These sweeping cuts to transportation will bring New Yorkers back to an era of struggling to get a ride, particularly for communities of color and in the outer boroughs.”
-LJU5L6Xll7_-Ce5rSz2.foodForThought: Is a cap on ride-share vehicles in New York City necessary reform, or a setback for the transportation industry?
-LJU5L6Xll7_-Ce5rSz2.name: Uber and Lyft Cap in NYC
-LJU5L6Xll7_-Ce5rSz2.shortTitle: Uber and Lyft Cap in NYC

-LJYdwOV0XgHnP7qHFRJ.description:
• Yesterday, August 9th, Vice President Pence announced the details of the Trump Administration’s plan to create a new U.S. Space Force, first proposed by the president several months ago.
  • The new Space Force would be a sixth, separate branch of the military. According to Pence, the Administration plans to establish the Space Force by 2020 and allocate $8 billion to fund it over the next five years.
  • Pence described the need for the particular armed force using defensive rather than offensive terms. Pence stated that it was time to “prepare for the next battlefield where America’s best and bravest will be called to deter and defeat a new generation of threats to our people, to our nation.”
  • Creating a fully operational, independent Space Force will require approval from Congress.
-LJYdwOV0XgHnP7qHFRJ.foodForThought: Is the creation of a new U.S. Space Force a good idea? Is the recently outlined plan for the new military branch realistic?
-LJYdwOV0XgHnP7qHFRJ.img_attr: Trump Make America Great Again Committee
-LJYdwOV0XgHnP7qHFRJ.name: Update on President Trump's Space Force
-LJYdwOV0XgHnP7qHFRJ.shortTitle: Update on President Trump's Space Force

-LJncyMfgVfoF9hC6KMc.description:
• This weekend, August 11th and 12th, marked the one-year anniversary of the Charlottesville ‘Unite the Right’ rally and counter-protests, which resulted in violence and the death of a counter-protester.
  • A “Unite the Right 2” white supremacist rally occurred in Washington DC on Sunday to mark the anniversary. It was organized by Jason Kessler, the organizer of the original Charlottesville rally.
  • Many counter-demonstrations were organized by various groups opposed to Jason Kessler’s white supremacist beliefs.
  • The turnout for Kessler’s anniversary rally was extremely low, with an estimated 20-30 of Kessler’s supporters in attendance, and large crowds of counter-protesters.
  • The rally ended without violence, and only one arrest was made, reportedly due to a police confrontation after the rally had ended.
-LJncyMfgVfoF9hC6KMc.foodForThought: How should the United States handle white supremacists? What is the significance of yesterday’s events in DC on the anniversary of Charlottesville?
-LJncyMfgVfoF9hC6KMc.name: The Charlottesville Anniversary

-LJqeBjHxzIFt010dQtO.description:
• Last week on August 7th, Elon Musk announced his intentions to take his company Tesla private.
  • In in a tweet, Musk stated he had the “funding secured” to buy back Tesla stock from stockholders at $420 a share.
  • The announcement drove up Tesla stock 11% in one day, but this week has brought uncertainty as to whether the funding is as secure as first conveyed.
  • According to Musk, the funding will come from Saudi Arabia’s public interest fund, pending a financial and internal review.
  • The original announcement via twitter, with its assurance of funding, has reportedly brought a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry, as well as at least two class action lawsuits claiming the tweet broke securities laws.
-LJqeBjHxzIFt010dQtO.foodForThought: Will Elon Musk's plans to take Tesla private work out? Is it a smart move for the company?
-LJqeBjHxzIFt010dQtO.name: A Private Tesla?

-LJvz8JerREnJqY8qfHN.description:
• Omarosa Manigault-Newman, former political aide to President Trump, recently released a new book that is harshly critical of the president.
  • The book, titled Unhinged, labels the president a “racist,” and hints that Omarosa has recordings of President Trump using the n-word while filming The Apprentice.
  • On Sunday morning, in an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press," Omarosa claimed she had also recorded a conversation in the White House Situation Room.
  • White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said that the book is "riddled with lies and false accusations" and accused Omarosa of "trying to profit off these false attacks."
  • On Tuesday, Trump tweeted: “When you give a crazed, crying lowlife a break, and give her a job at the White House, I guess it just didn’t work out. Good work by General Kelly for quickly firing that dog!”
-LJvz8JerREnJqY8qfHN.foodForThought: How important is Omarosa's newly-published book? Should her allegations be taken seriously?
-LJvz8JerREnJqY8qfHN.name: President Trump vs. Omarosa

-LK1rW51N-QYWgrJekg8.description:
• Yesterday, August 15th, President Trump revoked the security clearance of John Brennan.
  • Brennan is the former director of the CIA, serving in the role from March 2013 to January 2017. He has been an outspoken critic of President Trump. 
  • In a statement regarding the action, Press Secretary Sanders said: “Mr. Brennan has recently leveraged his status as a former high-ranking official with access to highly sensitive information to make a series of unfounded and outrageous allegations.”
  • Sanders also claimed that the administration is currently reviewing clearances for a number of additional former intelligence and security officials, including James Comey, Susan Rice, Lisa Page, and Sally Yates.
-LK1rW51N-QYWgrJekg8.foodForThought: What were President Trump’s motivations for cancelling John Brennan’s security clearance? How significant is this action?
-LK1rW51N-QYWgrJekg8.name: John Brennan's Security Clearance Revoked

-LK7JNwDAeSTvdwIXRC3.description:
• Earlier this month, the editorial board of The Boston Globe proposed a coordinated campaign for newspapers across to country to respond to the president's rhetorical attacks on the media and journalists with locally produced editorials.
  • Yesterday, August 16th, a reported 350 newspapers participated in the event.
  • The editorial effort elicited both praise and criticism, with some newspapers pushing back against the initiative and others choosing to simply sit it out.
  • President Trump condemned the Globe and the corresponding event, claiming that the Globe was participating in “collusion with other papers on free press,” and that he is in support of “true freedom of the press” via twitter. 
  • Following the wave of editorials and responses, the U.S. Senate unanimously adopted a non-binding resolution affirming support for a free press and declaring that “the press is not the enemy of the people.”
-LK7JNwDAeSTvdwIXRC3.foodForThought: Did the Boston Globe’s initiative have an impact on the country’s political discourse? Is so, was it positive or negative?
-LK7JNwDAeSTvdwIXRC3.name: Wave of #FreePress Editorials

-LK9M4c6---TD1qv8YlQ.description:
Democratic nominee: Senator Ben Cardin

  • Ben Cardin is the incumbent candidate. He was first elected to the Senate in 2006 and is running for reelection to a third term.
  • Prior to his 2006 election to the Senate, Cardin was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. He was first elected to the house in 1986 and was reelected nine times.
  • Cardin currently serves on the following Senate committees: Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Committee on Environment and Public Works, Committee on Finance, Committee on Foreign Relations, and Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship.

View the Platform

Republican nominee: Tony Campbell

  • Tony Campbell is a professor of politics at Towson University, a veteran of the United States Army, and an author of two books: America Today and A More Perfect Union.
  • Campbell has served on the Executive Committee of the Maryland Republican Party and the Baltimore County Charter Review Commission.
  • He is currently a member of the P-20 Leadership Council for Education, a board member of a charter school in Baltimore, and serves on the Baltimore County School Board Nomination Commission.

View the Platform
