-LK9XeD8LrX4hVRfUCj2.name: Maryland Senate Election on November 6, 2018

-LKKnpVDciVGFuRPdYyF.description:
• Last Tuesday, August 14th, a Pennsylvania grand jury issued an 884-page report detailing rampant child sexual abuse connected to the Catholic Church in the state, dating back to 1940.
  • According to the report, the members of the grand jury found that there were over 1,000 identifiable cases of children who were of victims of sex abuse by over 300 Catholic priests.
  • The grand jury report was the result of an investigation spanning more than two years, the broadest examination yet into child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church. The scope of the investigation included six out of Pennsylvania’s eight Catholic dioceses.
  • The report included horrific details pertaining to different cases of sexual abuse, as well as the intentional concealment efforts and cover ups made by “church leaders who preferred to protect the abusers and their institution above all.”
  • Addressing the inability to file criminal charges against more than two of the priests, the members of the jury wrote: “We are sick over all the crimes that will go unpunished and uncompensated.”
  • The grand jury provided a list of recommendations to the Pennsylvania legislature, including: eliminating the statute of limitations for child sexual abuse in the state, expanding the window for civil suits, strengthening mandatory reporting laws, and changes for non-disclosure agreements in respect to law enforcement.
-LKKnpVDciVGFuRPdYyF.foodForThought: What is the appropriate response to the recent grand jury report concerning child sex abuse by Catholic priests in the state of Pennsylvania?
-LKKnpVDciVGFuRPdYyF.name: Pennsylvania’s Grand Jury Report: Widespread sexual abuse among Catholic dioceses
-LKKnpVDciVGFuRPdYyF.shortTitle: Sexual abuse among PA Catholic dioceses

-LKNKhYkQqwIYRlo-h_c.description:
Republican Nominee: Senator Ted Cruz

  • Ted Cruz is the incumbent candidate. He was first elected to the Senate in 2012 and is running for his second term.
  • Cruz was a candidate for the Republican nomination for President in 2016. He received over 7.8M votes in the primaries and won 12 states.
  • During his first term as U.S. Senator, Cruz served on the Committee on Armed Services, the Committee on the Judiciary, the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, the Committee on Rules and Administration, and the Special Committee on Aging.

View the platform

Democratic Nominee: Beto O'Rourke

  • Beto O'Rourke has served three terms in the U.S. House of Representatives as the representative for Texas's 16th Congressional District (El Paso), having been first elected in 2012.
  • He has served on the Committee of Armed Services and the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, and he is currently a member of the New Democrat Coalition and Congressional Arts Caucus.
  • Prior to his election to Congress, O'Rourke was on the El Paso City Council from June 2005 to June 2011.

View the platform
-LKNKhYkQqwIYRlo-h_c.foodForThought:
Not Registered?

Register to vote in Texas
-LKNKhYkQqwIYRlo-h_c.name: Texas U.S. Senate Election

-LKOy_lDWul9UGubCpZ0.description:
Democratic Nominee: Senator Tim Kaine

  • Tim Kaine is the incumbent candidate and has represented Virginia in the U.S. Senate since 2013. He is running for re-election for a second term.
  • In the U.S. Senate, Kaine sits on the Committee on Armed Services, the Committee on the Budget, the Committee on Foreign Relations, and the Special Committee on Aging.
  • Kaine was elected as the Governor of Virginia in 2005 and served from 2006-2010 and he was chairman of the Democratic National Committee between 2009 and 2011. He served as Mayor of Richmond between 1998 and 2001.
  • In 2016, Kaine was chosen as Hillary Clinton's Vice Presidential running mate in the 2016 Presidential Election.

View the Platform

Republican Candidate: Corey Stewart

  • Corey Stewart is currently the At-Large Chairman of the Board of County Supervisors in Prince William (PWC) - the 2nd largest and fastest growing county in Virginia.
  • In 2017, Stewart sought the Republican nomination for Governor of Virginia and narrowly lost to Ed Gillespie.
  • Stewart was the Virginia state chair of the Donald Trump's 2016 Presidential campaign, and co-chaired the Republican Party of Virginia's "Team Virginia" field and communications campaign in 2016.
  • Stewart has had a career as an international trade attorney.

View the Platform
-LKOy_lDWul9UGubCpZ0.foodForThought:
Not Registered?

Register to vote in Virginia
-LKOy_lDWul9UGubCpZ0.name: Virginia U.S. Senate Election

-LKRjOZSDaZyx4Sherwm.description:
• Ahead of upcoming confirmation hearings scheduled to vet Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, members of Congress have been seeking details and records about his credentials.
  • On Monday, August 20th, the National Archives and Records Administration released a two-page memo authored by Kavanaugh in 1998 related to Independent Counsel Ken Starr’s investigation of then-President Bill Clinton.
  • In the memo, Kavanaugh makes it clear that he believed attorneys prepping to question President Clinton should not go easy on him.
  • Within it Kavanaugh states: “The president has disgraced his Office, the legal system, and the American people by having sex with a 22-year-old intern and turning her life into a shambles.”
  • The memo also suggested a list of potential questions for Clinton that include graphic and explicit details about the president’s sexual relationship with Monica Lewinsky.
  • Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell hopes to confirm Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court by October 1st.
-LKRjOZSDaZyx4Sherwm.foodForThought: What effect will the recently released memo authored by Kavanaugh have on his upcoming confirmation hearings, if any?
-LKRjOZSDaZyx4Sherwm.mobile_img_attr: U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
-LKRjOZSDaZyx4Sherwm.name: Update on Brett Kavanaugh

-LKWX6wF6FvWDTiruR4n.description:
• Yesterday, August 21st, saw significant legal defeats for Paul Manafort and Michael Cohen, who are now both facing prison.
  • Manafort’s first of two trials concluded with a jury finding him guilty on eight out of eighteen charges. He was convicted on five counts of tax fraud, one count of failing to disclose his foreign bank accounts, and two counts of bank fraud. A mistrial was declared on the other ten charges.
  • Cohen officially surrendered to the FBI and pleaded guilty to eight charges: five counts of tax evasion, one count of making false statements to a financial institution, one count of willfully causing an unlawful corporate contribution, and one count of making an excessive campaign contribution at the request of a candidate or campaign.
  • Both men have connections to President Trump. Manafort, a longtime political consultant, served as the president’s campaign chairman from June to August 2016. Cohen was President Trump’s personal lawyer from 2006 to May, 2018.
  • In a statement, Cohen admitted to making an illegal campaign by paying $130,000 to adult-film actress Stephanie Clifford to prohibit her from publicly discussing an alleged sexual encounter with President Trump. Cohen said he worked “with and at the direction of the candidate” and was later repaid by the president.
  • In the wake of yesterday’s events, President Trump told reporters: “Paul Manafort is a good man. ... It doesn’t involve me but it’s a very sad thing. ... It had nothing to do with Russian collusion.” Regarding Cohen, the president tweeted this morning: "Michael Cohen plead guilty to two counts of campaign finance violations that are not a crime."
-LKWX6wF6FvWDTiruR4n.foodForThought: What is the significance of Manafort's conviction and Cohen's guilty plea? What do yesterday's events mean for President Trump?
-LKWX6wF6FvWDTiruR4n.name: Manafort, Cohen, and what it means for President Trump

-LKWspj6sEz0Hf5atbyS.description:
• Silent Sam is a famous statue on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus that depicts a Confederate soldier.
  • The statue, erected in 1913, was dedicated to the UNC students and alumni who lost their lives while fighting for the Confederate Army during the Civil War.
  • This past Monday evening, August 20th, Silent Sam was toppled over by a group from among an estimated crowd of 250 protesters.
  • The police are currently investigating the vandalism and assessing the full extent of damage.
  • Nobody was injured during the incident.
-LKWspj6sEz0Hf5atbyS.foodForThought: Were demonstrators justified in pulling down the Silent Sam statue? What is the best course of action for the university to take in the aftermath of Monday night's events?
-LKWspj6sEz0Hf5atbyS.name: Silent Sam Toppled by Protesters

-LKZhJDU6LcVvSaJ9bwT.description:
• Asia Argento, an Italian actress, singer, model, and director, has been a prominent leader and voice in the #MeToo movement.
  • Argento was among the group of women who reported and publicly accused film producer Harvey Weinstein of sexual harassment, assault or rape.
  • This past week, The New York Times published allegations that Argento sexually assaulted actor Jimmy Bennett.
  • According to the report, the assault took place in a California hotel room in 2013 while the two actors were working together on a movie. At the time, Bennett was 17, younger than the legal age of consent in California, and Argento was 37.
  • The Times report also stated it had received documents confirming Argento agreed to make payments to Bennett when he first accused her.
  • Argento has denied the accusations, telling the Huffington Post: "I am deeply shocked and hurt by having read news that is absolutely false. I have never had any sexual relationship with Bennett."
-LKZhJDU6LcVvSaJ9bwT.foodForThought: What type of impact will the accusations against Argento have on the greater #MeToo movement?
-LKZhJDU6LcVvSaJ9bwT.name: Sexual Assault Allegations against #MeToo's Asia Argento

-LKfwu_q_u5Y_6tYiaP9.description:
• Recently, tech giants and politicians have been in the news for their efforts to fight cyber attacks and misinformation campaigns by foreign adversaries.
  • On Monday, August 20th, Microsoft shared that it thwarted the early stages of an attack on two conservative think tanks and the U.S. Senate by a Russia-linked group, "Fancy Bear."
  • Facebook, Twitter and Google also made headlines by removing hundreds of Russian and Iranian-linked pages, groups and accounts from their platforms.
  • The Democratic National Committee, which was the victim of an attack during the 2016 election by the aforementioned "Fancy Bear", announced that it had successfully stopped hackers from accessing its voter database. However, it turned out that the suspected hack was actually a security test initiated by the Michigan Democratic party.
  • Meanwhile, politicians have been working on a bill called the Secure Elections Act. The bill, introduced by Sen. James Lankford (R-OK) and supported by some politicians from both parties, mandates that every state conducts a statistically significant audit following a federal election and incentivizes the purchase of voting machines that produce paper records.
  • On Wednesday, Sen. Roy Blunt (R-MO), the chair of the Senate Rules and Administration Committee, cancelled a committee session that would have led to a full Senate vote on the Secure Elections Act in October, effectively stalling the bill.
-LKfwu_q_u5Y_6tYiaP9.foodForThought: What is the best way to secure elections from cyber threats? Is more tech or less tech needed?
-LKfwu_q_u5Y_6tYiaP9.name: How to Secure Elections from Cyber-attacks

-LKvnqLMD4kIGIpgzxqO.description:
• On Saturday, August 25th, John McCain died in his home in Arizona after a year-long battle with brain cancer.
  • McCain served in the United States Navy during the Vietnam War, spending five and a half years as a prisoner of war after he was shot down by the North Vietnamese. 
  • Following his military service, McCain began a notable 36-year political career that included two terms in the House of Representatives, six terms in the Senate, and a presidential run in 2008 as the Republican nominee. 
  • Though generally considered a conservative politician, McCain was nicknamed a “maverick” for a perceived willingness to challenge other Republicans on certain issues. 
  • A memorial service will be held at Washington National Cathedral on September 1st. At McCain’s request, Former Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama will deliver eulogies, and he will be interred at the United States Naval Academy Cemetery.
-LKvnqLMD4kIGIpgzxqO.foodForThought: What is the legacy John McCain leaves behind? What lessons do his life and career offer the United States?
-LKvnqLMD4kIGIpgzxqO.name: A Farewell to John McCain

-LL-YV5hr3hlUsniKUkt.description:
• Yesterday, August 27th, negotiations between the United States and Mexico resulted in an agreement that paves the way toward replacing NAFTA (North American Free Trade Agreement).
  • In a statement from the Oval Office, the president said: “We're going to call it the United States-Mexico Trade Agreement, and we'll get rid of the name NAFTA. Has a bad connotation, because the United States was hurt very badly by NAFTA for many years.”
  • Approval from Congress is needed in order for the deal to be finalized, and U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said, “we expect to submit our letter to Congress beginning that process on Friday.”
  • The deal struck yesterday excludes Canada, a former party of the original NAFTA. The United States will likely re-engage with Canada following these negotiations with Mexico to reach a finalized trilateral deal.
  • The US–Mexico agreement includes “an agreement on the amount of North American content a vehicle must have in order to pass duty-free across borders.”
-LL-YV5hr3hlUsniKUkt.foodForThought: What is the significance of the U.S.–Mexico trade agreement announced yesterday? Will the deal successfully replace NAFTA?
-LL-YV5hr3hlUsniKUkt.name: A NAFTA Replacement?

-LL5oIg4xRw606ZYv7HF.description:
• With the U.S. Open tennis tournament currently ongoing, women’s tennis outfits have been a subject of controversy.
  • Much discussed is Serena Williams, who wore a black, skin-tight catsuit in May when she competed in the French Open.
  • Subsequently, the French Tennis Federation announced it would be making changes to the tournament’s dress code regulations which would ban the catsuit outfit.
  • This week, Serena Williams wore a two-toned, one-sleeved leotard and a black tutu in her first match against Magda Linette in the U.S. Open.
  • The ensemble was a collaboration between designer Virgil Abloh and Nike.
-LL5oIg4xRw606ZYv7HF.foodForThought: Are women players' tennis attire at professional tournaments problematic? Do dress code regulations help preserve respect for the game, or impose elitist restrictions?
-LL5oIg4xRw606ZYv7HF.name: Serena Williams and the French Open Dress Code
-LL5oIg4xRw606ZYv7HF.notification: Serena Williams and the French Open Dress Code

-LL7aG4IBvnJlH8xbzXz.description:
• On Tuesday, August 28th, primaries were held in Florida, Arizona, and Oklahoma. Results from the Florida gubernatorial race and the Arizona U.S. Senate race garnered national attention.
  • In Florida, U.S. Rep. Ron DeSantis decisively won the Republican nomination for governor. On the Democratic side, Andrew Gillum, the mayor of Tallahassee, pulled off an upset victory.
  • The Florida governor's race is notable for the stark contrast between DeSantis and Gillum. Both candidates have platforms that reflect the ideological wings of their respective parties.
  • With Gillum's nomination, the Democratic party has three African-American gubernatorial nominees. Currently, no U.S. state has an African-American governor.
  • In the Arizona Senate Race, Rep. Martha McSally secured the Republican nomination for U.S. Senate, defeating more conservative opponents like Joe Arpaio. She will face Democratic nominee Rep. Krysten Sinema.
-LL7aG4IBvnJlH8xbzXz.foodForThought: What are the broad takeaways from this week's primaries? How are Republicans and Democrats evaluating the results?
-LL7aG4IBvnJlH8xbzXz.name: Takeaways from the August 28th Primaries
-LL7aG4IBvnJlH8xbzXz.notification: How are Democrats and Republicans evaluating this week's primary results?

-LLCtew53qZ9abIAFIHm.description:
• On Thursday, August 30th, the Department of Justice (DOJ) publicly sided with a group called Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) that is suing Harvard University.
  • SFFA claims that Harvard consistently gives Asian-Americans lower rankings on a "personal score." This score is used by the admissions team to evaluate soft skills like likeability and courage.
  • In a court filing, the DOJ said that "Harvard's race-based admissions process significantly disadvantages Asian-American applicants compared to other racial groups."
  • 25 Harvard student groups have backed Harvard in the lawsuit and other prominent U.S. colleges like MIT and the entire Ivy League have come to Harvard's defense.
  • The lawsuit is scheduled to go to trial in Boston in October.
-LLCtew53qZ9abIAFIHm.foodForThought: Does Harvard need to admit more Asian-Americans? More broadly, should race and ethnicity be considered in the college admissions process?
-LLCtew53qZ9abIAFIHm.name: Is Harvard Discriminating Against Asian-Americans?

• Colin Kaepernick, the NFL quarterback most associated with the kneeling protest movement in the league, recently signed an advertising deal with Nike.
  • Nike announced yesterday that Kaepernick will be the new face of its “Just Do It” campaign.
  • The first advertisement image pictures Kaepernick in black and white with text reading: “Believe in something. Even if it means sacrificing everything."
  • Kaepernick has also been featured in the news recently due to a development in his legal complaint filed last November.
  • Kaepernick alleges in his grievance that NFL owners colluded to keep him out of the league, and two weeks ago a system arbitrator denied the NFL’s request to dismiss the case, meaning there could be enough evidence to bring the case to a trial.
-LLZ_BEs_qxjRHqBokg8.foodForThought: Was the choice of Colin Kaepernick as the face of Nike's "Just Do It" campaign a good decision or a poor one?

-LLe4CslsvzQ8WHLyggY.description:
• Bob Woodward, the famed investigative journalist behind much of the original news reporting on the Watergate scandal and co-author of All The President’s Men, will soon release a new book.
  • Woodward’s upcoming non-fiction book is called Fear: Trump in the White House, and details the presidency and administration of Donald Trump.
  • The book is set to be released on September 11th, 2018.
  • According to The New York Times, the book is based on "hundreds of hours of interviews with firsthand sources, contemporaneous meeting notes, files, documents and personal diaries," and it paints a negative portrait of a dysfunctional White House.
  • In August, President Trump and Woodward spoke via phone about the book. Trump reportedly told Woodward: "You know I'm very open to you. I think you've always been fair," and both men expressed sentiments that they should have had an interview before the book was written.
  • Yesterday, September 4th, White House Press Secretary Sanders released a statement dismissing the book, claiming it is: "nothing more than fabricated stories, many by former disgruntled employees, told to make the president look bad."
-LLe4CslsvzQ8WHLyggY.foodForThought: How big a deal is Bob Woodward's new political book? Will it be a significant blow to the White House?
-LLe4CslsvzQ8WHLyggY.mobile_img_attr: LBJ Library photo by Jay Godwin
-LLe4CslsvzQ8WHLyggY.name: Bob Woodward's New Book: A White House Tell-all
-LLe4CslsvzQ8WHLyggY.notification: Bob Woodward's New Book: A White House Tell-all

-LLjQqR0xJZQXe7HSoxU.description:
• Yesterday, September 5th, The New York Times published an opinion article written by an anonymous senior official of the Trump administration entitled “I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration.”
  • The author claimed to be part of a group that is “working diligently from within” to thwart the misguided tendencies of the president.
  • The article is highly critical of President Trump, describing his leadership as “impetuous, adversarial, petty and ineffective,”
  • According to author, the efforts being made to contain the president’s temperament and bad judgement have resulted in a “two-track presidency,” where senior officials act in contrary to the president’s wishes in order to preserve the nation’s best interest.
  • President Trump has called the article a “gutless editorial,” and Press Secretary Sanders issued a statement harshly condemning the author and calling for his or her resignation.
  • To read the op-ed in its entirety, click here.
-LLjQqR0xJZQXe7HSoxU.foodForThought: What motivated the anonymous author to pen this op-ed? What are the consequences of the article being published?
-LLjQqR0xJZQXe7HSoxU.name: Anonymous Op-Ed from a Trump Senior Official
-LLjQqR0xJZQXe7HSoxU.notification: Anonymous Op-Ed from a Trump Senior Official
-LLjQqR0xJZQXe7HSoxU.shortTitle: Anonymous Op-Ed from a Trump Official

-LLof8uUe9kn2M0BJwM4.description:
• First Man is a 2018 American biographical drama film about astronaut Neil Armstrong, based on the book First Man: The Life of Neil A. Armstrong by James R. Hansen.
  • The film stars Ryan Gosling as Neil Armstrong, and chronicles the years leading up to the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969.
  • First Man premiered on August 29th at the Venice Film Festival, and is scheduled to be released in the United States on October 12th by Universal Pictures.
  • Last week, it was reported that the film would not include a scene of Armstrong and Aldrin planting the American flag on the Moon. This has sparked a wave of criticism, most notably from some Republican politicians.
  • Senator Marco Rubio described the omission as "total lunacy." President Trump commented: "It's unfortunate. It’s almost like they’re embarrassed at the achievement coming from America, I think it’s a terrible thing."
  • The Armstrong family released a statement saying "We do not feel this movie is anti-American in the slightest.”
-LLof8uUe9kn2M0BJwM4.foodForThought: Should the filmmakers of First Man have included a scene portraying Armstrong and Aldrin planting the American flag on the moon? How significant is this decision?
-LLof8uUe9kn2M0BJwM4.name: The new Neil Armstrong Movie "First Man"
-LLof8uUe9kn2M0BJwM4.notification: The new Neil Armstrong Movie "First Man"

-LM0XBM-sNKjzzemSZjk.description:
• On Saturday, 20-year-old Naomi Osaka defeated Serena Williams in the U.S. Open tennis final by a score of 6-2, 6-4.
  • Controversy surrounded the match over arguments traded between chair umpire Carlos Ramos and Serena Williams, and Williams’s subsequent penalization.
  • First, Ramos issued Williams a warning for receiving illegal coaching through hand gestures. Although Serena's coach later admitted to making hand gestures, Williams denied that she cheated.
  • Next, Williams broke her racquet in frustration after a serve and this led Ramos to impose a one-point penalty.
  • Williams demanded an apology, calling Ramos both a “liar” and a “thief.” Ramos then issued a third violation for verbal abuse — which carried a one game penalty — against Williams. This game gave Osaka a 5-3 lead in the second set.
  • After the match, Williams was penalized with a $17,000 fine, $10,000 of it for her remarks to the umpire.
  • At a press conference following the match, Williams accused Ramos of sexism and said she will defend women’s rights and equality.
-LM0XBM-sNKjzzemSZjk.foodForThought: Does Serena deserve praise or criticism for her actions during the U.S. Open finale? Was it a fair match?
-LM0XBM-sNKjzzemSZjk.name: The 2018 Women's U.S. Open Final
-LM0XBM-sNKjzzemSZjk.notification: Does Serena deserve praise or criticism for her actions during the U.S. Open final? Was it a fair match?

• On Friday, September 7th, former President Barack Obama delivered a speech to a large group of mostly college students at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
  • Many believe the speech was a preview for the message he will be delivering in the months leading up to the November midterm elections.
  • On Saturday, Obama campaigned in California in support of several Democratic candidates for the House, and this week he heads to Ohio to endorse Democratic gubernatorial nominee Richard Cordray. It is reported that Obama's campaign activity will continue through October and will include fundraising appearances.
  • The former President has previously been largely quiet when it comes to the current political administration and climate, but his speech on Friday offered some of his most direct criticism of President Trump and his allies.
  • Obama spoke of a backlash occurring against progress, stating "it did not start with Donald Trump, he is a symptom, not the cause. He is just capitalizing on resentment that politicians have been fanning for years," as well as: "the politics of resentment and paranoia has unfortunately found a home in the Republican Party."
-LM5cGIMeVGFRZqdeCuk.foodForThought: Will Obama's message ultimately help Democratic candidates or motivate the Republican base?

-LMIBbF4ZeQszYcB6qQe.description:
• A crowdfunding campaign aimed at Senator Collins has garnered controversy this week for its unusual tactics.
  • Collins is a moderate Republican senator from Maine, and she is considered a potential pivotal vote on the confirmation of Kavanaugh.
  • The “Be A Hero” campaign – organized by national health activist Ady Barkan and the groups Mainers for Accountable Leadership and the Maine People’s Alliance – asks for donations to a future Collins opponent if she votes “yes” on Kavanaugh. If she votes “no” the money would be refunded to donors.
  • The fund reached a significant milestone on this past Tuesday as it surpassed $1 million.
  • Collins has likened the fundraising effort to bribery, and Cleta Mitchell, a Republican elections attorney, called for both the Department of Justice and FEC to investigate this crowdfunding campaign, saying it may violate election laws.
  • The groups behind the campaign maintain they are within their first amendment rights.
-LMIBbF4ZeQszYcB6qQe.foodForThought: Is the technique used by the crowdfunding campaign targeting Senator Collins problematic or protected?

• This week marks the 10-year anniversary of the global financial crisis.
  • The crisis began in 2007 in the subprime mortgage markets and developed into a full-blown international banking crisis after the collapse of Lehman Brothers on September 15th, 2008.
  • Aggressive fiscal and monetary policies were implemented to prevent a potential collapse of the global financial system. Financial institutions were the recipients of large bailout packages.
  • The crisis was followed by a prolonged economic downturn known as the Great Recession.
  • In 2010, the U.S. passed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. The law placed stricter regulations on the financial industry and also aimed to protect consumers from abusive lending and mortgage practices.
-LMN2tkTfq4QHGrZMXNz.foodForThought: Is our financial system more stable today? Do we need to be worried about another crisis?
-LMN2tkTfq4QHGrZMXNz.name: Reflections on the Financial Crisis - 10 Years Later
-LMN2tkTfq4QHGrZMXNz.notification: Is our financial system more stable today?

-LMbbxbNpfru_iJKXBgv.description:
• Yesterday, September 16th, Christine Blasey Ford went public with her accusation that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when he was in high school.
  • The allegations first surfaced last week in the form of a letter that had been in the possession of Senator Dianne Feinstein, the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, since July.
  • In an interview with The Washington Post, Ford described Kavanaugh pinning her to a bed at a Maryland party they attended in the early 1980s, trying to remove her clothing, and putting his hand over her mouth when she tried to scream.
  • Kavanaugh has repeatedly denied the allegation, saying again on Sunday: “I categorically and unequivocally deny this allegation. I did not do this back in high school or at any time.”
  • Democrats have called for a delay in the key Senate Judiciary Committee vote scheduled for this Thursday on whether or not to recommend that Kavanaugh be confirmed to the Supreme Court by the Senate.
  • Ford has said she is willing to testify about the incident before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
-LMbbxbNpfru_iJKXBgv.foodForThought: What should happen next in regard to Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation process?
-LMbbxbNpfru_iJKXBgv.name: Sexual Misconduct Allegations Against Kavanaugh

-LMgm00oC2TO_wXwJjly.description:
• Yesterday, September 17th, President Trump announced that he will be imposing new tariffs on about $200 billion in Chinese goods, and he threatened to add hundreds of billions more in an effort to continually pressure China to change its trade practices.
  • According to administration officials, the 10% tax on Chinese imports will take effect on Sept. 24, will increase to 25% at the beginning of 2019, and will affect a wide range of imported goods.
  • The announcement further escalated the rising trade tensions between the two nations, prompting an immediate response from China.
  • This morning, China announced retaliatory tariffs on $60 billion in 5,207 U.S. goods, which will also take effect on Sept. 24.
  • It has been reported that Chinese officials are considering U.S. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin’s invitation to participate in trade negotiation talks in Washington, but currently there has been no final decision made.
-LMgm00oC2TO_wXwJjly.foodForThought: What will the rising tariffs imposed by the U.S. and China mean for the national and global economy?
-LMgm00oC2TO_wXwJjly.name: New Tariffs Intensify U.S.–China Trade Tension

-LMlzqbdMUEFxdwasUDF.description:
• On Monday, September 17, President Trump ordered the declassification of excerpts from an array of sensitive documents related to the FBI’s investigation into Russian election interference.
  • The declassification order pertains to portions of FBI transcripts, text messages, and other law enforcement and intelligence material.
  • The White House released a statement saying the president had directed the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and the Justice Department to declassify the documents "at the request of a number of committees of Congress, and for reasons of transparency."
  • Experts have said the move represents unprecedented presidential involvement in an ongoing investigation that involves several of his close associates.
  • According to a spokesperson from the Justice Department, the presidential request will be met with a review process to ensure national security. After that, the documents are still not likely to be made immediately public: they will presumably be first released to specific congressional committees.
-LMlzqbdMUEFxdwasUDF.foodForThought: Should President Trump have ordered these documents to be declassified? How will this decision affect the ongoing Russia investigation?
-LMlzqbdMUEFxdwasUDF.name: President Trump Declassifies Russia Investigation Documents
-LMlzqbdMUEFxdwasUDF.notification: Should President Trump have ordered the declassification of Russia investigation documents?

-LMr_pSYn-HQzuhbTuwo.description:
• On Sunday, September 16th, Christine Blasey Ford went public with her accusation that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when he was in high school.
  • Dr. Ford stated that she was willing to testify about the incident before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which subsequently scheduled a Monday hearing to include her testimony.
  • However, citing threats and harassment Dr. Ford has received since Sunday, her attorneys informed committee chairman Chuck Grassley on Tuesday that a full investigation by law enforcement officials must be conducted before Ford will testify.
  • Chairman Grassley has indicated that the committee is likely unwilling to wait on an investigation, stating on Tuesday: “Nothing the FBI or any other investigator does would have any bearing on what Dr. Ford tells the committee, so there is no reason for any further delay.”
  • According to her attorneys, Dr. Ford “remains open to reasonable steps” when it comes to cooperating with the committee.
-LMr_pSYn-HQzuhbTuwo.foodForThought: Is it reasonable to delay the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing until a full investigation into Dr. Ford's accusations against Kavanaugh is conducted?
-LMr_pSYn-HQzuhbTuwo.name: An Update on the Kavanaugh Confirmation Process
-LMr_pSYn-HQzuhbTuwo.notification: What comes next for the Kavanaugh confirmation process?

-LMwS1tn53qxmJKhhm4n.description:
• In the last 1-2 years, there has been a significant rise in rates of electronic cigarette smoking (also called vaping) among teenagers.
  • The FDA recently described teen vaping as reaching “an epidemic proportion,” and it has vowed to take a "series of critical and historic measures" to curb the trend.
  • The agency issued more than 1,300 warning letters and fines to convenience stores, gas stations and other stores over the summer for selling e-cigarettes to minors, which it described as the FDA’s “largest such action in history.”
  • The FDA has also recently given companies that make the most popular e-cigarettes among teenagers — JUUL, Vuse, Blu, MarkTen XL and Logic — 60 days to prove they can keep the devices away from minors. If they cannot, the FDA warns that it may pull the devices from the market.
  • The FDA explains that it is attempting to balance two goals while rolling out regulations: a) keeping electronic cigarettes available to adults who don't want to start smoking traditional cigarettes or are trying to quit and b) keeping the e-cigarettes out of the hands of young people.
-LMwS1tn53qxmJKhhm4n.foodForThought: Is the FDA taking appropriate steps when it comes to the regulation of electronic cigarettes sales? Should stronger action be taken to curb the teen vaping trend?
-LMwS1tn53qxmJKhhm4n.name: Is the FDA doing enough to regulate e-cigarettes sales?
-LMwS1tn53qxmJKhhm4n.notification: Is the FDA doing enough to regulate e-cigarettes sales?

-LNB-bo0pSpnP_jZT0eq.description:
• Three days ago on September 21st, The New York Times reported that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein had secretly discussed recording President Donald Trump as well as invoking the 25th Amendment to remove the President from office.
  • As Deputy Attorney General, Rosenstein was responsible for overseeing Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian election interference and possible collusion with the Trump campaign.
  • Rosenstein has denied the New York Times report, stating: "I never pursued or authorized recording the President and any suggestion that I have ever advocated for the removal of the President is absolutely false."
  • It is being reported that Rosenstein expects to be fired, and has considered tendering his resignation.
  • As of 11:30 A.M. on September 24th, neither his dismissal nor his resignation have been confirmed, but Rosenstein has been summoned to the White House and will meet with chief of staff John Kelly today.
-LNB-bo0pSpnP_jZT0eq.foodForThought: What would be the political consequences of Rosenstein's resignation or dismissal?
-LNB-bo0pSpnP_jZT0eq.name: The Fate of Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein
-LNB-bo0pSpnP_jZT0eq.notification: The Fate of Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein

-LNBSmxtlJ2LGndFNtxt.description:
Republican Nominee: Governor Bruce Rauner

  • Governor Rauner is the incumbent candidate, having served as the Governor of Illinois since 2015.
  • Prior to his election, he was the Chairman of R8 Capital Partners and Chairman of the private equity firm GTCR.
  • Rauner has also served as the Chairman of Choose Chicago, the not-for-profit that serves as the city's convention and tourism bureau, and as Chairman of the Chicago Public Education Fund.
  • During his governorship, Rauner has signed an executive order blocking "fair share" union fees from state employee paychecks, proposed $4.1 billion in budget cuts, and vetoed the both Illinois state budget and an increase in the state income tax.

Democratic Nominee: J. B. Pritzker

  • J.B. Pritzker is a prominent Chicago venture capitalist. He is a co-founder and managing partner of Pritzker Group Private Capital.
  • Pritzker has served as Chairman of ChicagoNEXT, Mayor Rahm Emanuel's council on innovation and technology, which is Chicago's digital startup center.
  • Pritzker founded Democratic Leadership for the 21st Century, a national organization dedicated to attracting voters under the age of 40 to the Democratic Party.
  • In the 2008 Presidential election, Pritzker served as the national co-chairman of the Hillary Clinton for President campaign and as a delegate to the 2008 Democratic National Convention and the 2016 Democratic National Convention.
-LNBSmxtlJ2LGndFNtxt.name: Illinois Gubernatorial Election

-LNBTnSYWWex5B3I88te.description:
Republican Nominee: Governor Larry Hogan

-LNFzQ9LfgZLTTL5gbYV.description:
• Recently, the idea of adding Puerto Rico as the 51st state in the United States has resurfaced in the public narrative, especially in connection to U.S. federal assistance in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.
  • Nearly one year after Hurricane Maria devastated parts of Puerto Rico, Representative Jenniffer González, the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico, filed a bill in Congress that would pave the way for Puerto Rico to become a state in 2021.
  • Currently, the political status of Puerto Rico is that of an unincorporated territory of the United States. As such, Puerto Rico does not have voting rights in its federal legislature nor in electing its federal head of government. But, in contrast to U.S. states, Puerto Ricans are not subject to federal income taxes.
  • The most recent referendum to approve statehood was held in Puerto Rico on June 11, 2017. Voters overwhelmingly chose statehood by 97.18%; however, voter turnout was historically low, at only 23%.
  • Yesterday, September 24th, in an interview on Cleveland’s WTAM radio, President Trump declared himself an “absolute no” on statehood for Puerto Rico, stating: “with the mayor of San Juan as bad as she is and as incompetent as she is, Puerto Rico shouldn’t be talking about statehood until they get some people that really know what they’re doing.”
-LNFzQ9LfgZLTTL5gbYV.foodForThought: Has Hurricane Maria significantly reframed the question of Puerto Rican statehood? What are the pros and cons of making Puerto Rico the 51st state?
-LNFzQ9LfgZLTTL5gbYV.name: Statehood for Puerto Rico?
-LNFzQ9LfgZLTTL5gbYV.notification: Has Hurricane Maria significantly reframed the question of Puerto Rican statehood?

-LNLTm5heHc6wJYQGM0K.description:
• Tomorrow, September 27th, the Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hear the testimony of Christine Blasey Ford, the woman accusing Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault from decades ago.
  • Judiciary Committee Republicans hired Rachel Mitchell, a Phoenix-based sex crimes prosecutor to question Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh on Thursday.
  • Earlier this week, allegations surfaced from a second woman accusing Kavanaugh of sexual aggression in college.
  • This morning, a third accuser has come forward, represented by lawyer Michael Avenatti. The woman, Julie Swetnick, claims that Kavanaugh and others, as high school students, spiked the drinks of girls at house parties with grain alcohol and/or drugs to “cause girls to lose inhibitions and their ability to say ‘No.’ ”
  • Kavanaugh has continuously denied all allegations. On Monday night, he and his wife went on Fox News for an interview with Martha MacCallum, saying: “I am looking for a fair process, a process where I can defend my integrity and clear my name.”
  • The Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a vote Friday on Judge Kavanaugh’s nomination.
-LNLTm5heHc6wJYQGM0K.foodForThought: Is Kavanaugh’s confirmation process a reckoning for the #MeToo era? What is the best course of action forward?
-LNLTm5heHc6wJYQGM0K.name: Brett Kavanaugh Confirmation Controversy Continues
-LNLTm5heHc6wJYQGM0K.notification: Is Kavanaugh’s confirmation process a reckoning for the #MeToo era? What is the best course of action forward?

Jared Golden is a current member of the Maine House of Representatives, representing District 60.

Golden was first elected to the state chamber in 2014, and he has served as the Chair of both the Elections Committee and Joint Rules Committee.

Golden was in the United States Marine Corps, serving combat tours in Iraq and Afghanistan.

-LNNnHZoDf9drM5rRL8h.description:
• Over the last week, world leaders have gathered in New York City for the 73rd session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA).
  • On Tuesday, September 25th, President Trump delivered an evening address to the UN delegates.
  • The speech echoed the nationalistic theme and message that Trump used in last year’s 2017 speech to the UN General Assembly.
  • The president touted American sovereignty and his “America First” agenda, saying, “We reject the ideology of globalism and accept the doctrine of patriotism.”
  • President Trump also heralded the successes of his presidential administration, which he described as having “accomplished more than almost any administration in the history of our country,” a statement which elicited scattered laughter from the audience.
  • Though President Trump appeared briefly flustered by the laughter, claiming he “didn’t expect that reaction,” he later told reporters, “Oh it was great. Well, that was meant to get some laughter so it was great.”
-LNNnHZoDf9drM5rRL8h.foodForThought: Is "America-First" a good foreign policy doctrine? How should the laughter during President Trump's United Nations speech be interpreted?
-LNNnHZoDf9drM5rRL8h.name: President Trump's 2018 U.N. Speech
-LNNnHZoDf9drM5rRL8h.notification: President Trump's UN Speech: Unexpected Laughter, Sovereignty, and "America First"
